element_texts.text: Completed

268 West St. North 
Hillsdale, Mich: July 15, 1893  
My dear Aunt Anna: 

 We were so very glad to get your good letter day before yesterday. The postman went  right by at first and said he had nothing for us but he came back  in a few minutes with the letter saying that he had forgotten it. I return Mrs. Jones' letter, which I am very much obliged to you  for getting for me and to Eddie  for letting me read. What a dear, sweet soul she is! I am so sorry she has business troubles and can imagine just how she  deprives herself in order to help that little grand-daughter. She  evidently wishes that she could 

cross-written across top:
Lizzie sends love and says that she would like a letter too. She forgot to pack Dr. Crume's? receipt in her last letter, but says she will send it to Aunt Mary at Remsen.
Completed

release us from our note, when we ought really to be paying back all that she let us have.     

 I am very glad that she doesn't let Eddie pay back any that he had. 
 We are all quite wilted and nearly melted by the weather this week. 
 I hope you have not the conscience to be chilly these days. If you have, I can boast over you for I have even laid aside my inseparable companion the faithful old red shawl.   Mrs Davis and Ida were in last night and they facetiously asked me if I had to have a fire, these days Lizzie heartlessly remarked that I managed to get along with the kitchen fire. 
 Well, you and I are fellow sufferers in this cold and cruel world. We can sympathize with each other and exchange shiver for shiver can't we?
 Many thanks for the Pulsatilla. I was not suffering for it. but thought I
Completed

would like to have it on hand Lizzie did not have any, but there was enough in the little package for us both.   The Aldriches are living on Prof. Gurney's house now,  while they are away for the summer   Bennie came over last night and invited Eva and me down there. We had a nice little visit, and some ice-cream. They were much surprised to hear of Eddie's marriage.

  I attended Nettie Dunn's wedding last Wednesday night There was a large company there, mostly people from College Hill. Nettie looked very sweet in white silk. and the green was nice-looking. Prof. Dunn performed the ceremony, and did it in his happiest vein. There were a great many very useful and beautiful presents. Holden sent down a "Soo" souvenir spoon for me to take. She had three dozen solid silver
Completed

tea-spoons, besides several souvenir and berry spoons.  

   I expect to take the steamer for home, Monday evening, July 24th Yes see my visit is "long-drawn- out" but both of my physicians have advised it, Dr. Moore thinks I ought to stay all summer. but Holden thinks he has lived alone about as long as he can. I have been improving very fast since I went to see Dr. Andrews.
  I wish Aunt Mary could have made John and Azia a little visit. It was nice she caught a glimpse of him. We will write to her soon. I think that John and Azia are planning to go home with me. I shall be very glad of their company. We shall hope to hear from you after. 
  Please give my love to Eddie, Ella and the children. and accept a large share for your precious self.        
     Very lovingly,
   Hattie
Completed

Sault Ste-Marie Michigan                        
    September 11th . 1893 

My Dear Aunt Anna:               

   It seems a long, long time since we have heard from you. Very likely it is my own fault but that, you know, doesn't make it any easier to bear. We have been at home now nearly seven weeks. The first four weeks, John and Azia and Clarence spent with us. Then soon after they left, we all went down the river about thirty miles to Sailor's Encampment to spend a couple of weeks with the Johnston girls, of whom I told you, their Indian descent etc. They have a little shanty of two rooms right near the river and also a "lodge" made of hemlock and birch bark
Completed

The shanty was given up to us at night, while the girls occupied the lodge, and their father and mother and brother occupied tents. Their brother, "Howard" has charge of the range lights along the river for which he receives fifty dollars a month, as long as the boats are running It was pleasant being in sight of the river, where we saw so many large steamers and barges constantly passing. Holden counted thirty-six one day, and didn't see nearly all them. He and Eva went fishing several time and Eva proved to be the best fisherman. She caught seventeen perch one day, while Holden only  caught one. Eva got a large pike on her hook one day, but  when they tried to get it into the boat, it broke the line, and
Completed

carried off hook sinkers and all. They have no regular services on the Island, so Holden preached  both Sunday evenings that we  were there. I had a hard cold all the time I was there, and  was sick abed twice, with chills  and fever. We came back sooner  than we expected on this account. I don't know what I should  have done if I had not had that dose of medicine you put up for me, for there was no doctor within reach. These little pellets soon relieved me however,  and I think my faith was strengthened a good deal, as  well as my body. I had to laugh at Miss Johnston though, (in my sleeve), for she took two of  those smallest pellets of Arsenicum,  just to see how it tasted, and  she said it made her feel sick all night.
Completed

Since we came home, I have been feeling a good deal better, thought my cold and cough still trouble me. 

   My stay at Hillsdale did me so much good. I didn't feel like the  same person when I came back.  I have a good girl in the kitchen  now, so hope to keep from get ting so run down again. 
   I wonder if Aunt Mary is beginning to think about coming back from the east, and what you are planning to do this fall and winter. I hope you will stay in the state, for you are so near and  dear to us we want you within visiting distance! We hope to  be nearer you all, sometime. We all join in very much love to you, and to Eddie and family Eva is planning to answer Zaidee's dear little letter, before long. Very lovingly, as ever,
Hattie
Completed

Hillsdale, Michigan June 24th, 1876?  
My Dear Aunt Jennie:-                                  

 I believe I am owing you a letter, am I not? At any rate it is time I was, so I guess I will write and give you a chance to make me. It is over a week now since Commencement, but I don't seem to get much rested. Perhaps I am "constitutionally tired", but I guess I shall feel better after our journey we are thinking of making. And I must tell you about that. We expect to leave here the tenth of July and go first to Washington, where we shall stop a few days, and then go to Philadelphia 


Written across the top: 
year. We regret it very much but Frank is obliged to get there as soon as possible on account of his business and it is considerable cheaper going that way. We hate to lose them terribly, especially the Baby Claire but it can't be helped. I wish you would write before we start if you can. Give a great deal of love to all, and take a large share for yourself - as ever lovingly- Hattie
Completed

and spend one or two weeks there, then to New York city for a day or two, and then to Remsen, which I think will be nicest of all. So we shall see you about the  last of July. We are going with a  family, Mr. Winson's people, and some other, and expect to enjoy it very much. Father thinks the journey will do mother and me good, and I think a good deal the same myself! Indeed, I don't know but I was the first one who suggested it!--However I think dear old Remsen will be the crowning point of all and I expect to look forward to that with longing and almost impatience, through the weeks spent at other places. I want to gain ten pounds while I am gone
Completed

for I only weigh ninety pounds now and I have weighed ninety-nine, and I was the lightest one in our class. My greatest ambition is to weigh a hundred and ten, but I never expect to attain to that. It is well to have high aims in life though_ 

 You wouldn't guess that I was an Alumna of Hillsdale College, and a "B.S.", to read such nonsense, would you? But actually, I didn't see any difference, when I came down from the stage after speaking my little piece and receiving my diploma, I didn't feel a bit metamorphosed into anything, or anybody very wise or big, but just the same little goose I always was. I don't think graduating is a farce though by any means, I got four bouquets.
Completed

Mother wants me to take my exercises with me and inflict them on you. I don't know though, I like you pretty well and I haven't hardly the heart to. Perhaps if you want to you can buy me off with onions after I get there.     Frank came out to see me graduate after all. He couldn't stay away when the time came, but I shall want to see him just as much at Remsen for he only staid here three days as he had to go back on account of an old yearly meeting of his. I do hope they will have a camp meeting at Trenton while we are there, so we can go. Do you suppose Aunt Mary can come home while we are there? I hope so. Perhaps she can come with us right from New York. How nice that would be. Frank and Lizzie start for Lewiston Wednesday. They go through Canada, so they will not be able to visit
Completed

Hillsdale, Michigan, January 2nd, 1877  
My Dear Aunt Jennie: -                                 

    I have a letter commenced to you in my writing desk, dated December 28th, but I can't finish it for the last sentence written is only just begun and I can't think for my life what it was I was going to say! So you see I have made a new start. Whether I am able to finish this with out interruption, I do not know now as well as you will when you receive it.      The only thing of importance that I said in the unfinished sheet was that I could not tell how it happened that I had left your last letter so long unanswered, and come to consider it, that was not of much importance either, for it would be hard for anyone to tell 

written across the top:
none sure, and when I do write I at least have the pleasure of expecting an answer, whether it comes or not. We all sympathize very much with Grandma, I do hope she will be more comfortable soon-   Aren't you all tired of the cold weather? Michigan is the state for me! With much love to all, and especially yours lovingly,

Hattie
Completed

how I could neglect such a super extra good letter. I expected when I received it to answer it immediately, and  perhaps that was the very reason why I  didn't, for father says "the unexpected always takes place".  But then you  know I have been sick too, and the others have written so often that I have thought I could send a little "anytime", and I am beginning to learn that "anytime" most generally means "never".  Those things that are in the most danger of never being accomplished are such as can be done "anytime", don't you think so? We are all appalled just now by the news of that terrible railroad disaster in Ohio. How peculiarly sad seems the death of so widely renowned a man as P.P. Bliss, with all his family, and yet how few doubtless, were as well prepared as they.     

Two young ladies here in College received word yesterday that their father
Completed

was on the ill-fated train, coming to spend New Year's with them.   

  Many are still in suspence as to whether they have lost friends or not., it seems dreadful to think of.                          
  I have been meaning to write to some of you ever since Aunt Sarah and Uncle Will came out, to influence you to send them a letter at least every other day. At first they couldn't seem reconciled to not receive one every mail and if wrung my heart to see them disappointed so often, but now I think they are contented if two come every other day. Now don't think I am writing this to tease them!   
  I often wonder if their letters seem as few and far between to you, as yours do here. It seems strange the mails are so irregular, and play such tricks with the letter's.  
  We have made us a new game that we have lots of fun playing. I think
Completed

John Eddie would like it. Johnnie wrote five Alphabets on (five times twenty six) squares of pasteboard, putting each letter on both sides of the square, and then we mix them all up and each one selects letters for any word he thinks of, then disarrange them and change. One wouldn't think it would be so difficult to tell what word was intended when all the letters are there. Do you like such ways of passing an evening occasionally?  I suppose Aunt Sarah wrote you about the Christmas Tree at the church, we went to see. It was the first (and only) festival of its kind I have attended in Hillsdale.    Don't you think Aunt Anna better ask me directly what makes me so still instead of making roundabout inquiries, especially when she owes me a letter?  However I am not going to keep still any longer, it doesn't pay, for when I write no letters I receive
Completed

Hillsdale, Michigan 
January 20th, 1877  
My Dear Aunt Jennie:-                              

    I am completely overwhelmed with gratitute and astonishment at your promptness in answering my letter. And so you see I am hastening to write again lest you may all feel kind of lost in knowing that you are not owing me a letter. It would be an unheard of state of things for none of you to be owing me, wouldn't it!  I have been thinking seriously since yesterday of challenging Aunt Mary to a poetry match. I know I could write more than four lines if I got such an inspiration as she evidently had. If I was the Muse of Poetry I wouldn't visit her again unless she could pay me better than that for my trouble. But of course her 

written across the top
use of my molasses than you do! The idea of trying to black the stove with it You must have imagined the fumes would reach Uncle Will and help his Asthma. Perhaps that was it I believe he was a little better about that time! There! There! Shut up the stove! I am going to close! Very hastily, but as ever lovingly - Hattie
Completed

machine may have broken after such a strain. Tell her I think she ought to be careful about publishing this until she gets a copyright for it might lead to a dispute as to the authorship of it. If Longfellow or Bryant should claim it there might be difficulty in convincing the world that it came from an (as yet) obscure and unknown poet. In such a case I think I should feel it my duty to come forward and tell the world frankly that I wrote it. That wouldn't be true, of course, but it would be heroic, now wouldn't it, to admit that you wrote such a thing! Well I'll have Aunt Mary sending me some quieting powders that aren't all sugar if I say much more. So I will continue my letter to you, I guess. I must confess that Johnnie writes very few letters except to Ohio, but what can the poor fellow do with a letter coming an average every other day
Completed

and no one to answer them but himself! Uncle Will and I have repeatedly offered our services both in noting the contents and returning answers to the letters but so blind is he to his own interests that he rejects our offers every time. I hardly know what to tell you of the person who so occupies his attention, for I fear I may be repeating what you have al ready heard from other sources. But I fancy if Aunt Sarah could be persuaded to remain here until spring she would have the pleasure of receiving another neice into the family. It will be nice for me to have a  sister again, will it not! Ah, but no one can fill little Lizzie's place!   

  Oh I do hope you and Aunt Anna and Grandma will come and make us a good long visit next summer. It would be perfectly delightful!
Completed

And I would show you what a nice little housekeeper I shall be by that time! Bring John Eddie along too, and then perhaps I can go through my cook-book in order, as I have so often wished to do. It will be so nice to have some one to eat up the things when I don't have very good luck.  There, I didn't mean to scare anybody. Tell John Eddie to come and I won't do any such barbarous thing. It was horrid of me to think of it. We shall have the cream of the land, churned, that will be the nicest kind or buttermilk you see. But I believe my letter is really rising above its usual height of absurdity, and I must close before you get quite to the point of using it as a persuader to the fire. I made some delicious gingersnaps yesterday. Won't you have one? Uncle Will ate the biggest one there was and then said they weren't good. Can you imagine my emotions? --You see I make a better
Completed

embossed rose at top of page            
Hillsdale, February 3rd, 1877  
My Dear Aunt Jennie:-                            

     Your last letter created quite a stir in our usually quiet household. I mean your last letter to me. It made us all laugh heartily at Johnnie's expense. I think many such letters would exasperate him into turning his attention in your direction. This one would doubtless at any other time than within four weeks of his wedding.  
   Won't it be nice for me to have a sister again? I expect it will be just like Johnnie to monopolize her though
Completed

don't you? He has just come from town and brought the second number of P. P. Bliss and Sankey's Hymn Book. One piece in it "The Changing Bells of Time" I  heard sung most beautifully by an Evangelist who was here the first part of this week. His name is Spencer and he has the richest sweetest voice nearly that I ever heard. The meetings here continue to be very interesting. Thirty arose for prayers at one time. Many are young people, and some quite advanced in life.    

 Tell Aunt Sarah that Mr. Childs is selling all his goods at a reduced rate, though they are not injured in the least by smoke or anything else.
Completed

I got mother some seventy-five cent flannel for sixty cents, so you see the reduction isn't very much though it is worth accepting.  Tell Uncle Will that Mr. Coolly's wife is in here now and she is as cool as he, besides being decidedly more talkative and it's enough to drive anyone frantic who is trying to write a sensible letter, as you know mine always are! I must tell you how smart mother and I were this morning. We had breakfast at half past seven and after that we cleared up the breakfast dishes, filled the lamps, made the beds, put the chicken on to boil, cooked some squash and made five large pies
Completed

before ten o'clock. Then after that I made biscuits and got dinner. Mother has been clear out to the gate this afternoon. I think we are getting along realy nicely. There is a new proprietor in the Laundry here now and we get our clothes more regularly than we did. One of the Professors here in College, Mr. Fisk, has been obliged to go to his old home in New Hampshire on account of his health. We went Tuesday, so if Uncle Will had only waited one day he might have had some of  most "original" company he ever met. Can't you and Aunt Anna come out at Commencement time? I wish you could. Please write soon. Lovingly, Hattie
Completed

Hillsdale, June 25th 1877  
My Dear Aunt Jennie:-                                

  Nothing but the hurry and complete occupation of Commencement week could have kept me from writing and acknowledging those beautiful forgetmenots the day I received them. They came Wednesday morning, just the right time, and I put them down cellar in water immediately and they revived and became as sweet and fresh as could be desired. I showed them to the lady at the greenhouse and she said they were entirely different from any she ever saw. They were admired by all who saw them and I am most obliged 

cross-written across top:
our weeks seem to be nowadays. Mary is real good help. She does our washing and ironing now. You don't know how much I want to see you all or even any of you. Sometimes it seems as though I must. I know so little and have so many perplexities, and nobody to go to. Please write when you can Auntie Dear. Ever Lovingly, Hattie.
Completed

for your kindness than I can tell you. I fear though that you robbed yourselves, I had no idea of your sending so many. I must tell you about those plants you sent me when you first went back too. The forgetmenot, daisy, white pansy, and  that fine green vine with a yellow flower, are all in blossom and growing like everything. Our flower-seeds didn't come up very well so we are all the gladder of those little plants. Those plants that you rooted from slips while here are nearly all living and doing well. Both my vines are running up on trellis and cord as fast as ever they can, and the begonia is flourishing finely. You mustn't think that this dreadful writing is from my gold pen Aunt Jennie.
Completed

I am writing with a steel pen this morning because I am in a tearing hurry and am afraid of hurting the gold one. I do not mean to break that as I did my other. Do you know I just finished my black cambric dress about a week ago. Wasn't I slow?  But there were so many things to hinder me. It looks just as pretty as can be. Made in a Lolasaise? and trimmed with fine knife pleating. I cut it and all. Did you get to South Hadley? Or are you going, or are you there now? I have forgotten the time of the reunion. You know the reunions here are in '80, and one of the Alumni who came back to Commencement made me promise that if neither of us were married then I would attend the reunion supper with him. Only think of
Completed

making such an engagement three years beforehand. He is Principal of a High School in an Ohio city, and expects to go to Europe next year. I am going to the lake with him this afternoon, and it will be a perfect time to be on the water if it continues as pleasant as now. Are you as much afraid of these row-boats as Uncle Will, or do you enjoy such fun as much as I? We are going to commence canning strawberries today and expect to have these nearly every day this week. Then a carpenter is coming tomorrow to make those two back chambers into one and we have trunks and boxes and feather-beds and everything else (you remember) to take care of. So you see it will be a busy week as all
Completed

Hillsdale, July 4th, 1877  
Dear Aunt Jennie:-                       

  Here it is only nine o'clock in the morning and we have the work all done up until it is time to get dinner, and I have practiced my music for today, and all because we got up so early. You see being the "glorious Fourth" we couldn't sleep for the bells and guns and crackers. Johnnie fired crackers through the blinds of their chamber window before any of us were up, and then he tied some on the end of a pole and let them off close by my window. Wasn't that dignified proceeding, for a College Professor?! 

cross-written across top
drowned once- I should like to go every week and learn to row. Tell Uncle Will when he gets a farm he must remember and have a pond in the middle of it and then I will come and see him. But I must close and go do something more profitable.  Love to all from,            

     Hattie
Completed

I remember very well that it isn't my turn to write you Aunt Jennie, but it seems so long since we have heard from Remsen that I feel impelled to stir you up a little and find out if you are all asleep. We wrote to Aunt Mary yesterday. I suppose she will be in New York all summer, will she not? Azia expects to go to Ohio next week to visit her friends. She will stay three or four weeks and then Johnnie will go for her. I think I shall stay at home like a good girl most of the summer and keep my fun for next year. Father and I are planning for a nice trip then if everything goes right. We have just been loving those two small back chambers made into one and Johnnie and Azia are going to love
Completed

that and we shall fix up the front room for a spare chamber. So any time after the middle of July we shall be ready to receive guests. Now is the time to speak for accommodations! How many shall I enter from Steuben? I have been getting me some cloth for a white overdress. It is quite pretty and I  cut and made the overskirt yesterday with the exception of the trimming which will be Hamburg edge. You see I am getting smart, it does not take me six months to finish anything, any more. Mary has gone home to spend the Fourth, went last night and will be back tonight. She does our washing and ironing now and is real faithful about the work. Did you go to your class reunion as you thought of? We had
Completed

a letter from Frank and Lizzie the other day saying that they thought come of coming out at Christmas to  spend the Holidays with us. Wouldn't it be lovely if they could? Darling little Claire said that she was writing to her "dear, good, dear, sweet, Auntie Hattie". But they didn't send the letter. I thought it was too bad. Frank said she improved a great deal while she was out here. Father and I, Johnnie and Azia, and Professor Haynes and his wife all went down to Bawbeese Lake last week and spent the afternoon. We took our baskets of good things with us and had our supper in the grove. Father didn't like to go on the water but the rest of us went in a round boat too. I have been down this a number of times lately and haven't been
Completed

Hillsdale, Michigan                                                     
March 23rd, 1878 
Dear Aunt Jennie:-                             

 Your letters were very gladly received yesterday and I am sorry that I must answer in such a hurry, but father wants to take this to the office at ten and so I have only about half an hour to write in. I have been pretty closely occupied this week as there has been a musical convention held in town and I have attended every evening, and either morning or afternoon of each day. I went three times the first day but found that it was too much for me. Professor L. O. Emerson of Boston conducted it, and last evening we closed with a concert which went 

cross-written across top

It makes me very sad to think of your home bereft as ours is of a precious mother. But each loss draws us nearer to each other and nearer to our Heavenly Father.   
  We shall none of us have many more partings for we shall each be called ourselves.  If I can only be as well prepared as you all are I shall not dread the summons.
Completed

off very nicely. Professor Emerson as you know is a great composer of music and he gave us excellent instructions, dwelling particularly upon the importance, in singing, of light and shade, proper expression, and the distinct articulation of words.    

 I went into Court one afternoon this week for the first time in my life. There were several ladies in, and although the case was not particularly interesting, one of a chattel mortgage, I enjoyed it being so new to me.    
 Has Maggie's school commenced yet? I should think she would enjoy it if it is not too hard for her. I do hope we can see you all this summer, but I suppose it is not at all certain, we can tell but little about the future.  Dear Grandma was very, very kind to remember us children so and her loving thoughtfulness for us touches be very much. She and dear mother were just alike in thinking and
Completed

caring for each one. But it doesn't seem right for me to take my share for I do not need it and I fear you do.    

 If I had it I should never use it until I came in absolute need of it for it would seem like something sacred to me and too precious to spend unless from real necessity. But you have not much, and all your expenses to bear, and you may really need it, and so Auntie dear, if there is such a possibility I shall be glad to relinquish all claim to mine and let you Auntie have it. You have always been kind and generous to others in the largest hearted way, and now you ought to think of yourselves as I believe you never did yet.   
  But father is going and I must close. I hope you will all be very careful and not work or worry yourselves ill.   
  With a heart full of love to each one I am as ever, Your Loving,                                   
    Hattie
Completed

Hillsdale, May 31st, 1878
My Dear Auntie,
As it is not my turn to write to anybody I thought that I would heat coals of fire promiscuously and write to everybody. You Remsen people are splendid correspondents when you correspond, but when you don't you're horrid. Now you can take that compliment for just what it is worth as I shall not charge anything for it. We have been wondering if Eddie received the Latin books that Johnnie sent him. He happened to have duplicates, so he could send them as well as not. I hope we shall decide about our journey before long, but we are still undecided whether to go by Canada or through Utica. I very
top of page
of Remsen. But I think you said there were two of that name. Father is waiting to take this to the office so i must send a blank page this time. You may fill it out in imagination with all  the loving things I would like to say. With much love to each and all,
Hattie
Completed

much prefer the latter, but they have offered a discount to the Faculty on the other road, so we may feel like going so if it is much less expense. In that case we should visit Remsen on our way back, but if we go right through as I have a fairish glimmer of hope, we should stop with you a few days about the twentysixth of June.  You spoke Aunt Jennie in your last letter of writing to Frank N. If you haven't already, perhaps you would like his present address. It is "No. 62 Main Street, Buffalo, N.Y."  I am expecting him out in about a week to attend Anniversaries and Commencement.

  Azia is having her examinations this week. I shall be very glad when she is through for she is working too hard. SHe is one of the kind that will not slight anything, and when there is so much to be done she will do it and
Completed

do it well, even if she has to take the time out of her sleeping hours and sacrifice her health.

   We are having beautiful weather now, just cool enough to be comfortable. I have been having a dressmaker here at the house to sew for me for the last five days. She helped me a great deal, and made the least extra work and trouble of anyone that I ever had. We have to keep pretty busy with our regular house-work and getting ready for our journey, and Azia being in school and all. An Irish woman who helped us clean house has sent her little girl up to help us before school in the morning for the past week or two. I find a little assistance a great help where there are so many steps to be taken. Is John Griffiths' daughter Jennie married? There was a notice of a Jennie Griffiths marriage in a paper not long ago and she was
Completed

Hillsdale, Michigan
May 23rd, 1879.
Dear Aunt Jennie:-

   Father received a letter from Uncle William this morning enclosing these pictures and giving the following information in regard to them.

"John H. Lowell & Co. 21 Exchange Place, are Steel plate engravers and herewith I send you one of their late engravings of ex-Gov. Onslow Stearns of N.H. lately deceased. I knew Mr. Stearns and this is a good picture of him. I got it from
in margin
it. Excuse this short note for I must write a few words to dear Aunt Sarah.
Lovingly--
Hattie
Completed

them this A.M. and their lowest price is $125.00 each plate, and $1.50 for 100 engravings or pictures.

  I also send you a lithographic picture, from the the parties who got out those of Eld. John Stevens of Biddeford Me. Their prices are $20.00 each for Portraits, and $3.00 per hundred copies. If you order from either party you should send the best picture you have for them to copy from. "

He also says that he cut this picture two inches narrower, and two inches shorter than they were made, for convenience in mailing.
Just as I finished writing this last sentence father came in with his sad tidings from Remsen.  It is so two words obscured cannot realize
Completed

Hillsdale, October, 17th, 80.
Dear Aunt Jennie:
Your letter was very gladly received about a week ago, and your postal yesterday. We were considerably surprised to hear of Miss Williams arrival to this country. I trust that she will be more favorably impressed than was Uncle Nath., with the country and people. I know she will like her first cousins, anyway, whether she does the rest of the Americans or not. I have had some very pleasant letters from her, and should like very much to become acquainted. Do you think it would be improper, or unadvisable, considering all circumstances, to write her to visit us?
in top margin
ill. I feel very anxious about her. He didn't write any particulars only that she was very weak, and able to sit up but a moment at a time. My eyes still trouble me, but otherwise I am very well. Write soon please -- Love to each of you from, Hattie
Completed

Please tell me just what you think, for I am in considerable perplexity about it, and want your advice. You know I should enjoy a visit from her very much, but it might be embarrassing to other parties, and I am at a loss to know whether I should be doing the wrong thing to ask her or not. Please consider this confidential, Aunt Jennie, Dear, and give me your opinion. If you think it would be proper for me to write her to visit us, please give me her address. I don't want to shock her ideas of propriety at all, but I should like to see her very much. Azia is going to leave us this week, and father and I will find our family pretty small. We have a young lady working for her board, so there will be three of us. I believe I haven't written to you since Johnnie left Cleveland. He is at Bay City, in the state, now. He had a good opportunity to buy
Completed

out a gentleman's furnishings establishment, and so gave up his book trade. He has paid down partly for unclear business, and is to pay the rest out of the sales. He enjoys it very much, and seems to have found just the place for himself. He has rented a house and their goods have already gone. He has been there three weeks, and likes the people and the place. It is about a hundred and fifty miles north of here, and is a place of 22000 inhabitants. Azia likes the idea of living there very much and I hope father and I will go there when he gives up teaching. Johnnie says it is growing very fast and is a live business place. His clerk is going to board with them, so Azia will have three to provide for. I don't know what father will do this winter without Johnnie to help him about his wood and the other chores. He has thought some of having some
Completed

one of the students room here, and let them pay for their rent so. But he spoke the other night of John Eddie, and wondered if he wouldn't like to come out and enter College, and so board with us and help him about these things. He would be so much company for us we should enjoy it, and perhaps we could help each other in that way. Father has a scholarship, so he wouldn't have to pay any tuition only for incidentals (two or three dollars a term) and he is so far along in his studies that I presume he would be able to enter the winter term as advantageously as any. What do you and he think of it? Azia's brother Charlie, her mother, and Charlie's little girl, have been visiting us the past week. Charlie is quite a prominent lawyer in Bryan, Ohio, and graduated here in '70. I had a letter from Frank, not long since, saying that Lizzie was seriously
Completed

Hillsdale, July 21st, 1881.
Dear Aunt Jennie:-
I have neglected writing all too long, but have had so many things to try my eyes that I have put off many letters that should have been written. We were deeply shocked and pained to hear of Uncle Lewis' death, the news of which came so unexpectedly. The circle of loved ones in the other Home, will soon out-number those of us left here. How will Aunt Jane and my dear cousins bear this affliction? May they receive consolation from above, where alone it can be found at such times. I hope you may all have strength given you to bear it. I feel very anxious for you all, you know how
in margin
must not use anything astringent. Father is going to the office and I must close. Please excuse a hastily written letter. Aunt Louisa's health is much better than it has been. Please remember me with much love to Miss Williams. I intend writing her soon.
With much love to each of you dear ones.
Hattie
Completed

dear you are to me. I always think that my Remsen Aunties are a little nearer perfection that anyone else in the world. Partly because you are so good and lovable, and partly because you seem so much like my precious mother, who I know was almost without fault. 
We shall want to know how Aunt Sarah is. Hope she will improve fast. Lizzie and the children, with Aunt Louisa came last Tuesday. We are enjoying their company very much. Lizzie says to tell you that Anna is the best baby in the world. I am inclined to think she is too. She laughs a great deal, and very seldom cries. Her cheeks are as fat as little butterballs. I think her a remarkable pretty baby, much prettier than Claire used to be. Claire is quite a girl now. Almost a seven years old. She can read very well, and enjoys it.
Completed

She likes to romp too, and is happy if she can get her Uncle John to frolic with her. She is chattering like a magpie now, so I can hardly keep two wits together. Father enjoys them all so much. It seems so good to have our family together once more and Aunt Louisa here too.  She and father always thought so much of each other, they enjoy each others society once more very much. 
You asked me to tell you more about my eyes. I hardly know how much I have told or what to say. It is so much easier to answer questions than to start in and describe any trouble. They trouble me the most if I try to read, or get them heated in any way. The week after Azia left I did all this work myself, thinking we should enjoy it so much better if be alone, but being over the stove
Completed

so much was very bad for them, and they kept getting worse and worse until I was obliged to get a girl to come and help me. When they are bad I have such sharp pains shoot through them in the back part of the eye-ball, and can hardly hold them open. Sometimes it seems as though there was something slipping down back of one of them. The left eye is the worst. But the stranger part of it is that they look as well as they ever did.  When Aunt Louisa came she said "Why there is nothing the matter with your eyes".  I am very glad of this.  I never could stand "red eyes". But I feel quite anxious about them.  When they get tired they burn so, and shut up without any apology. I do nothing for them except bathe them in salt water. 
The oculist who seemed to understand them the best said there was inflamation of the retina, and I
Completed

Hillsdale, Mich.
Oct. 3, 1881
Dear Sister Jennie
We were happy to receive your letter, and Hattie thinks she will write you today; so I will put in a few lines. Glad you have having pleasant company and a good time this summer.  I little thought when we made you that hurried visit three years ago, it would be so long before we should visit again. Hope Sarah is gaining, and will soon be much better.  John Eddy is quite persevering about his education, and trust he will succeed in full. 
Our company are yet with with us. They are all well. Lizzie continues to improve, and now seem to be pretty
Completed

will. Claire enjoys it here greatly. She is now nearly seven years old, strong and active. She and I take baby out to ride most every day. Little Anna is one of the smartest, plumpest little ones you ever saw, hardly ever cries, but always so bright & cheery. She is about nine months now Sister Thompson is also enjoying her visit, but will probably go back to New England in a week or two. Lizzie thinks of staying till after Thanksgiving. Hattie will finally go to Cincinnati Wed. of this week. Of course we shall be anxious till she returns. It is very mild here, with considerable rain of late. A letter from Johnny today. They are doing nicely. All moving pleasantly in college with 375 students. Please write often.
With Much Love to you all,
J.J. Butler
Completed

Hillsdale, October 3rd 
Dear Aunt Jennie

I will only write  a little this morning, as I am very  busy, but I am sure we ought to  acknowledge your good letter. I hop to go to Cincinnati day  after tomorrow, if it is pleasant.  I dread it a little, as I must go  alone, but anything for the sake of  my eyes, and I should need the help of Providence too, if I had  ever so much human protection. How I wish you could all come  over here and spend this winter.  We should enjoy it so much,  but I suppose you would think  it too far.  It will be so lonely  for me after Lizzie and my Aunt  are gone.  I am going to sing for one of the societies tonight.  Just now a member of another society came to get me to sing
Completed

for them too.  I have the work to do today as our girl is washing, so I  shall not be able to do anything  towards packing until tomorrow.  If I go Wednesday, I hope to get back by Saturday. Claire takes  a great deal of comfort with the  locket you gave her.  She wears  it every Sunday.  She enjoys going  to church, very much. How is Maggie's health now?  And  Sarah Jane's?  Please give much  love to them. I should have  written them long before now, but  for my eyes.  I do hope Aunt  Sarah is feeling better.  Is Aunt  Anna's health good now?  You must all take care of  yourselves.  I want to see you  all very much.  It seems a long, long time since I visited  you in N.Y.  Write soon please. With much love Hattie
Completed

Hillsdale College building--image 
Treasurer's Office, Hillsdale, Mich., January 12th, 1882 
My Dear Aunt Jennie: 

  We intended to have written before this, but time has passed more swiftly than we thought. We feel very anxious for Aunt Sarah, but keep hoping to hear more favorably of her condition. This is a very trying winter, for everyone, but especially it must be so for one so weak. Tell her not to give up, the winter is half gone, and the spring will bring new strength and hope. We have heard nothing of Aunt Mary for a long time. What is her address now? Someone told Lizzie that she had moved from 433 W. 34th St. Is her health better than it has been, and is she doing well? Tell me all about her, please. I don't think much of losing track of one of my own Aunties. I should like to ask her if she knows anything of Dr. Goodman, oculist, of Philadelphia.
Completed

I have a great deal of confidence in Dr. Williams, but still I should like the opinion of one or two others. My eyes gain so slowly, sometimes I question if they are gaining at all. Still I must have patience, I know. What a perfect school of discipline in that respect, the world is! Lizzie writes that they are all well. Claire laboriously scrawls "Anna is good," which statement Lizzie fully sustains. She is certainly one of the sweetest tempered babies I ever saw. I think she must get her name and nature from the same source. I am sure Claire hasn't forgotten her Aunt Jennie, for she was going to write to you while she was here, but had so much correspondence to do with her Papa that I fear she neglected her other friends. She always wore her pretty locket when she went to church, or dressed up at all, and on state occasions, little Anna was allowed to wear it, though she was sure to hear from Claire if there were any motions made towards putting it in her mouth. I fear Aunt Anna would have been
Completed

shocked at her little namesake, if she could have seen with what perfect impartiality she would close her red lips upon the most tempting delicacy or--horrible to say--somebody's old shoe. She liked nothing better than to have her socks off, and shoes with what facility she could put her own foot into her mouth. But she is three months older now, and of course conducts herself accordingly. I presume all babies are very much alike, but I never saw one that seemed half as sweet and charming as Anna. Claire didn't interest one at all when she was a baby, though she is a dear little girl now, but Anna won my increasing admiration from the first. She must have lots of Everett
Completed

in her, I know. Father and I are alone now, except that there are two Theological students occupying the rooms that Johnnie and Azia had. I get along very well with the work. There is not so very much to do for two, and it is pleasant to have some occupation since I can use my eyes so little. Johnnie and Azia seem very happy in their work. We hope that they will spend the summer with us, as we hardly expect to make any long journey. How are Owen and his wife prospering? I can hardly realize that her is married. Do they keep house? I should like so much to see them both. Father's classes keep him quite busy. He is in from nine until twelve. I think he is well as usual this winter, he can stand mild winters better than severe. We shall hope to hear from you again soon. Hope you will all be sustained and encourage, and that we may all share some happy hours together yet. With much love to all, Hattie.
Completed

Hillsdale, January 8th, 1882
Dear Aunt Jennie:
We have been very glad of the postals which you have sent us so frequently, and will try to be more prompt in writing ourselves.  We feel very anxious about Aunt Sarah,but keep hoping for a change for the better. I think the hardest of the winter is past, these frequent changes of temperature must be very trying to a sick person, for they are easy to teh well. I would give so much to be near enough so I could be with you all now. Aunt Sarah's visit here the winter of seventy-six was of priceless benefit to us all. She was such a comfort to mother, and I know that the remembrance
Completed

of her pure, unselfish character, which showed itself in every act and word,  has made me want to be a better Christian, whether I have been one  or not.  I long to see her dear face  and talk with her once more.  God grant that I may, if it is His will.  Father and I are getting along after our usual fashion.  That is not very wild or boisterous, you know,  - at least as far as he is concerned.  And I can't make much rumpus by myself.  He is at his classes from nine in the forenoon until twelve, and down town about  an hour in the afternoon, so  I have the house pretty much to myself, a considerable part of the time.  I am not taking music this winter, but trying to favour my eyes.  These long evenings would be much more pleasant if we could read aloud, part of the time, but of course that is impossible.
Completed

Father has to use his eyes in the daytime as much as they will bear. So we both welcome the lengthening days. Do you ever hear from Johnnie? He wrote me last week that the thermometer had been 21 below zero there, The lowest it has been here was 2 below. And the next day there were heavy rains! A change in the weather is about all we can depend on. As someone said he other day, those who like variety ought to be suited. Does John Eddie continue to take part in that "debating club"? If so, here are two questions that were given the Harvard students for discussion - 1st "Ought members of the Cabinet to be responsible for Congress?" 2nd "Does the possession of a good memory afford any indication of the presence or absence of other mental powers."
Completed

I think I would like to belong to a debating club. They must be very interesting as well as instructive.  Wonder if girls couldn't carry them on as well as boys. I suppose J.E. would say No. because a woman must always have the last word, and so there would be no end to the first discussion.  It isn't so, though, is it?  How is Aunt Mary's health now? I hope to have a letter from you when you get time for it. Tell me how each one is, and how you are yourself. I must send this to the office, and so write no more this time.  Lizzie writes that Anna isn't very well, and Claire has been most sick. Such a trying winter for everybody. May our dear ones be mercifully spared to us. With much love to all Hattie
Completed

Hillsdale, Michigan,
June 20th 1888.
Dear Aunt Jennie and Aunt Anna:

   Your good letter came last Saturday, while John Eddie was here. How can I express my gratitude for your kind and generous remembrance of me! I thank you a thousand times for it, and I mean to get something with the money which I can always keep as a precious souvenir of my dear Auntie's priceless love. Claire and Anna were so much pleased with their presents too. Cousin Eddie showed Annas love to cousin Lise, and she would hold five half dollars in one little hand, and take off one at a time with the other. We had such a nice visit with Eddie. We were all very sorry to have him go. it seemed as though


and Johnnie can be here too. I hope you will visit soon again. We are so glad to get your letters.  We all join in hoping to see you this fall, and in much love. Your affectionate neice
Completed

the time flew while he was here. We haven't got over missing Lisa? yet. Every little while it seems we thought she must come into the room. we had a good letter from Johnnie this morning. He wishes that he could be here with us, but is busy and contented there. He sent Lise a little item from a Glens Falls paper speaking well of him. I do wish you could all be here at my wedding. If you will come out in the fall, I will come back and make a good long visit, and then this spring we expect to come back here to live. I rather think Lizzie will stay until spring. She needs a change, and it agrees with her here better than at Lewiston. We should all enjoy having you here more than I can say. It seems as though I couldn't give it up. I am glad Aunt Mary is going home
Completed

for a good rest. I do wish that was a good chance for her to practice here. Perhaps there might be. There are so many of the student girls that would prefer a lady doctor. Then if we keep a horse next year, as we think some of doing, she could go out in the country too. Holden will probably have a church to supply, near here, each year, and would need a horse. Then we can keep chickens if we want to and perhaps a cow. Holden has always lived on a farm and he understands taking care of everything. Would we have a happy family with you and Eddie, and father, and Holden and I. I do hope my eyes get well sometimes. They are my great trouble now. I wish Holden and I could go and visit you and Johnnie too for a wedding trip. It would
Completed

cost most too much, and he can't leave the church either. 

  We are going to live at his home this fall and winter. It hardly seemed worth while to furnish for house keeping for that little time. 
   Father is glad that we are going to be here for several years yet as he likes Holden so much and would dread to leave here. I suppose cousin Eddie is in Corry now. I sent him a card yesterday. You would have laughed to see him play with Claire. She thought it was just right, though she would pretend to get put out with him, some times. Anna began to get acquainted with him too, before he left. He and Johnnie are something alike, about being sure to make friends with the children. We expect Azia here week after next. It seems too
Completed

Hinckley, Ohio,
September 14th, 1880
Dear Cousin Eddie, 

  I don't know whether father has even answered your good and welcome letter, or not, but I remember your said you should not consider it wholly answered, until each one of us has written, so I hasten to do my part and shall expect a receipt in full, for the same. I am somewhat at a loss to know in what part of the country you may be found, at this time. But think I will send to the old place, and trust to Good Fortune (our especial friend) to send it to you.
  Oh - Cousin Eddie, please let me make you acquainted with your Cousin Holden. (Holden, this is Cousin Eddie). Here I want you

top margin:
rather hoped you would come and get them, and you may yet. Bring the Aunties with you and come to stay. You see I write as though we were there too, and we do intend to be in the spring. I shall hope to hear from you soon. Aunt Jennie owes me a letter too. Holden joins me in love to you all. As ever, your cousin 
Hattie
Direct, Hinckley, O. Medina Co. Mrs. H. A. Putnam.
Completed

to feel acquainted ever after, and be as good cousins as you and I have been. You know we never did anything worse than dispute about sweet cider. And Holden won't even do that, for he went and spoke in temperance the other night, and I just know I won't get any cider this year. — O DEAR! —

  They are sending out men to speak on the second amendment, all over the state, preparatory to the vote to be taken this fall in regard to the license law. They mean to abolish that if possible, and I hope they will succeed.  Holden spoke at Remsen Corners. (why didn't you go?) about six miles from there. Another man was appointed to speak with him, but was prevented from coming on account of the sickness of some of his relatives. 
 Mr. Waldron made us a little visit last week. Came Thursday, and
Completed

went back Thursday. He was as full of fun as ever. but managed to keep sober enough Sunday to preach twice for Holden. I don't know yet whether Mr. McCarthy is back at H. this year, or not. He is a Methodist, you know, and they have been trying to get him to go to Albion. Have you entirely given up going to Hillsdale? I thought you were going to take Hillsdale as the golden mean between New York and Kansas. It seems a long, long time since I have heard from any of you. Has Aunt Mary gone back to New York? I wrote to her a short time before I was married, and asked her if she would send me more aconite, and enclosed fifty or sixty cents - I forget which now) in postage stamps. As I have heard nothing from her since, I have wondered if she ever received this letter. I sent it to her
Completed

new address. Will you please send me her address when you write, as I am not sure that I have it now. We have had beautiful weather since I came here, and I have had even so many nice rider. I go with Holden to his second appointment at Royaltes, every Sunday, a distance of six miles. We generally take tea with some of his church members, and drive home in the evening. Week before last we attended a family reunion, where there were ninety-two guests. Did you receive our wedding announcement? I should have sent one to cousin Robbie Henry, if I had know his address. Did you receive the card I sent you when you were in Penn? You left several things at our house and I asked if you wished them sent on. As you didn't say in your letter, nothing was done about it. I
Completed

1328 Amsterdam Ave; 
New York, December 8th , 1890.
My Dear Eddie:

  I neglected to return your stamps, in my last letter, which please allow me to do now. You can imagine how much I wish you were here, just now, when I tell you that Mr. Lloyd Garrison spoke at Avon Hall last night, on the "Old Abolition, and the New," and tomorrow night Mr. Sarkey sings at a temperance rally. Now it isnt always at times like these that I miss you most, but there is a poignant sense of double loss, when I know of such treats which might be for me to enjoy, if I only had my good and gallant
Completed

cousin, to take me safely there and back. I am not sure but I would be be brave enough to go alone to hear these two, if they were in better parts of the city. But one is done near Av. D., and I would be almost reluctant to go there in the day time alone. The other is near Fulton St., where I should be lost completely. Holden has only two examinations this term, Hebrew and Theology. They occur two weeks from today and tomorrow. They had to omit some of the examination for lack of time. I suppose none of the students regret it much. How quickly a school year goes! I can hardly realize that we were nearing the end of the first term. Father has been reading the life of Jerry McAuley, and has been much interested in it. He has written an article upon it for the Star. Have you observed from the papers
Completed

how much favorable notice the Salvation Army has obtained lately? There was quite an account of their convention here in N.Y., published in the Independent lately. The husband of the Mrs. Booth we heard, is the second son of Gen. Booth of England.

  I haven't much time this afternoon, so I will not write more now. I shall hope to hear from you again soon. Tell me if the book arrived all right. 

As ever, 
Affectionately, Hattie
Completed

Hillsdale, Michigan
May 8th, 1890
My dear Cousin: 

 we were very glad to get your notes yesterday. We have thought of you great many times this week. I hope now, Thursday afternoon, you have reached your destination. It almost makes my head whirl for you, to think how long you have had to ride. I never, no never, no, not hardly ever want to ride so long at a time again, as we did coming here. Holden laughs at me, and says it tired so because I was tired out before we started, but that

in margin:
Aunt Anna Tuesday, and will try to write often. For fear I shoud fortet though, you write to me and remind me real often. 
Father and Lizzie and Holden and Claire and Anna and Eva and especially the editorial "we" wish to be rememberred to all of the Everett cognomen. With love, as ever, 
Hattie
Completed

Del. and L. road is so crooked it made me sea-sick, and I do wish we could go back some other way. But I suppose it is a holpless case, as long as we can get half fare on the that road. We were glad to know that you met a classmate, and had company part of the way. Holden had a card from M. Rohrabaugh yesterday, saying that he was on time to catch the local home. He was afraid one while that he wouldn't get home before Sunday. Our trunks didn't come until today. We were really afraid they were lost for awhile. It made us blue enough, for all our clothing was in there, and our sliver ware, photographs, etc. Holden helped telegraphing to find where they were, and finally found that they have been sent over the
Completed

Michigan Central, instead of the Wabash. They came this afternoon on the noon train. I think we shall be quite likely to remember our checks in future. Louise Williams called to see me this morning. She said she was "all broke up" because you didn't come. I comforted her by telling her that you might come in the fall. Lizzie said for me to tell you that you needed be afraid of being blockaded here in Sept., as the snow would be so deep then that all the trains would go on runners, and be all right. I thought she better have said that spring would just be opening then, for I am sure there is no prospect of its coming before that. I had more neuralgia yesterday, that I had all the time I was in New York.
Completed

If it torments me  this much I shall pack up and go back to Aunt Anna's yet. But I promise we shall have some warm weather between now and August. John and Azia left here yesterday (Wed.) afternoon. They will spend about a week with Azia's mother, and then start for Wash. I shall feel very anxious about the baby on the journey. Eva hasn't been well at all since we came. Today she has seemed a little better, and was quite bright when she went to bed. Mr. Holden called on us yesterday morning. He said I hadn't changed a bit since he saw me eleven years ago. I told him I liked to have people talk that way now I was getting old. Pres. Hacher's wife called last evening, and invited Lizzie
Completed

and me be one of her receptions for the students next Tuesday evening. We shall enjoy going very much. She says she has every member of the college at her house once during the spring term, each year. Then she invited a good many outside besides. They say her receptions are very pleasant and very informal. I had a letter from Susan a few days before we left New York. She wished to be remembered to "my favorite cousin," - if you can find out who that is. 

  Did Aunt Mary receive the report and program of the Medical College, which we sent her? I hope you are all together now, having a delightful time. I wish I could be there but for a few days. I wrote to
Completed

203 Brower St., Ypsilanti, Mich.,
November 3rd, 1891.
My dear Eddie: 

  You have been gone from our little home, just six hours, and I hope you will pardon my long delay in writing. I should have sent you a letter before now, of course, back unfortunately there was not train going at that time. Hence my long silence. I think you and Holden made pretty close connections, and my only regret is that you could not have come back with him, and had another visit. Yes, I have another regret too. I was so sorry when you started off that I hadn't hurried
Completed

and dressed Eva, so we could have gone to the station with you. I couldn't imagine why why I didn't, but I seemed to have the impression that I should not have time. I don't suppose you gave it a second thought, but I have felt badly about it ever since, and will until you visit us again. So for humanitarian considerations, you will have to come again as soon as possible.

  I am trying to get this letter to Hillsdale before you leave, so as to ask once more for Cousin Mary Ann's address. I forgot to put it down when you told it to me, and so it escaped my memory. Please send it to me, and tell
Completed

me whether to direct our letters to you in her care, or care of the Hospital. We shall be anxious to know how you found your father, when you get back. I am thinking of you all together, at Hillsdale, this afternoon, and wishing that we might all be there too. Holden is feeling pretty well, and glad to get home. He was very much surprised when I told him my story of the "settlement" which you said had taken place between us. So I "settled with you" did I? I thought you settled me, You did silence me back not my eternal sense of justice, and I feel that we owe you ten dollars plus. Holden says "Tell Eddie that I am
Completed

very sorry he gave me a wrong impression this morning, and that he would like to have you call and settle with him, now." He also says that he is very grateful to you for you kind services, and wishes you would come back and finish out your visit. 

  Tell Lizzie and the Aunties that I will answer their good letters, which we enjoy together so much, soon. Please remember to send me the address I asked for. With much love from us all, to each and all of you, Affectionately yours, Hattie. 

You left several things in your room. A box of blacking, wisp broom, package of candy, etc. You can have the same by calling for them, and proving property etc.
Completed

203 Brower St. Ypsilanti, Mich.,
December 22nd, 1891. 
My Dear Cousin:
A Merry Christmas, and a Glad New Year, to you! Perhaps the former may be a trifle late, but the letter will be timely. We were very glad to receive your too good, though brief, letters, and to know that you had already secured so good a position. I think you were very fortunate, and hope that you will like the work. One of the members of our church, a young man by the name of Becker, has a similar position in connection with Cleary's Business College, here. He was fitting up a home last
Completed

summer, and so was not able to travel for the college, and Mr. Clear told him so the fall that his being off the road during the summer, was a loss of three thousand dollars to the College. At that rate, they ought to pay a pretty good salary. I suppose you know that John has accepted a call to the church in Utica, Mich., north of Detroit, about twenty-four miles. We shall be glad to have him near us. He stopped here Friday night, on his way there. Rev. Mr. Van Auken, our state evangelist, took us by surprise last Thursday. He was holding meeting nine miles from here, and drove in. He came
Completed

again Saturday, and stand till Sunday afternoon, preaching for Holden in the morning. What do you hear from your father? Is his sight restored so that he can see well, now? I suppose it will be sometime before he can venture to us his eye enough to read much. What did he think of your charge? I wish you were in this state, but I suppose we cannot have everything we want. Holden had a wedding, the night before Thanksgiving, and now the day before Christmas, he is to have a funeral. There is a great deal of illness about here, just now. Eva is full of rosy anticipations of Christmas. There is
Completed

to be a Christmas Tree at the church, Friday evening, for the little ones, and her interest is divided between that and hanging up her stocking Christmas Eve. She is going to speak a little piece, at the entertainment at the church. 

  I hope you will find time and inclination, to write to us occasionally. Tell us about your work, and how you like it. Remember that this is one of your homes, and we want you to return to it, whenever you can. Hoping to hear from you again soon. Affectionately yours, Hattie. 

I need not tell yo that I am not in the letter-writing mood, tonight. I will not choose you for my victim next time I feel this way.
Completed

203 Brower St Ypsilanti, Michigan 
April 22nd, 1892
My Dear Cousin,
I enclose the check for your trunk. I am sorry we couldn't have sent it so you can get it today, but when Holden was down to attend to it yesterday, he found that the dray-man had left the trunk down town. He spoke with him about it, and this morning found it there at the depot, all right. These draymen are a necessary evil, I suppose, and are a help to us in the exercise of patience (!) I hope the delay will not annoy you too much
Aunt Mary's letter was gladly received this morning, also a letter for you from  Lansing, which
Completed

I will forward.
We were sorry to hear about Aunt Anna's illness. I hope your not going there Wednesday was not the cause of it. It was a great comfort to have you here,  but I fear I did wrong to let you stay. I hope Aunt Anna is improving fast and will have nothing to put her back.
I am not  feeling as well today as yesterday , but much better than I was the first of the week. 
It looks very much like rain and I hope if it comes it will be soon, so I shall not get caught at the farther end of town in it, where our Ladies Aid Society meets this afternoon.
I shall be so glad of a rest from all this church work, even for a few days if it is so I can go to Hillsdale in May. I forgot to
Completed

talk with you any more about that girl you spoke of at Merrill. Would you be willing to spare her from your church if we wanted her? And do you think she is still free to make an engagement? If you are willing, and think best, I would like to have you write to her and see what she would do. I think from what you said it would be a very good change for us to get good help, and we really ought to have it.
Please excuse this unsatisfactory little note. Eva's incessant little chatter has kept my thoughts in a whirl.
With much love to all, and an especial portion to dear Aunt Anna, (and another special portion to each of the others, including "that boy"
Affectionately , 
Hattie
Completed

I like it here better than I do Bay View. I know something daisy? to tell you. I wish I was at Hillsdale and I wish I was in New York and every-

____  The Unelected Infant ____

An unelected infant, sighed its little breath.
And wandered through the darkness, along the shores of death.
Until the gates of Heaven agleam with pearl , it spied,
And ran to them and clung there and would not be denied.
Though still from earth came mutterings, "You cannot enter in,
Depart into Gehenna, you child of wrath and sin".
If last the gates were opened; a man with features mild
Stooped down and raised the weeping unelected child.
Immortal light thrilled softly down avenues of bliss,
As on the infant's forehead the spirit placed a kiss.
"Who are you, thus to hallow my unelected brow?"
